captions.text:
&gt;&gt; [music] Stanford University.
[music]
&gt;&gt; My name is Christian. I'm a junior, majoring in Political Science.

&gt;&gt; I'm Karen Scribner, a senior majoring
in Human Biology.

&gt;&gt; Welcome to Stanford.
&gt;&gt; Our tour begins at Stanford Stadium,

home to Cardinal football.
Stanford Stadium was completed in 2006 and

holds 50,000 football fans.
This is the oval.

We've got the palm-lined sweep Palm Drive
leading up into the quad culminating in

the church.
This is <i>the</i> Stanford picture.

Welcome to the Main Quad everyone.
This is where the School of Humanities and

Sciences is located.
The Quad has been here since the

university opened in 1891.
&gt;&gt; Maples Pavilion is home to Stanford

volleyball and basketball.
Come out to Sunken Diamond to watch

Cardinal baseball.
&gt;&gt; The quad is made primarily of

sandstone.
Each column is unique because each was

carved by hand.
&gt;&gt; Avery Aquatic Center is one of the

finest collegiate aquatic centers in the
country.

&gt;&gt; Each graduating class gets a class
plaque in the Main Quad.

In it, class members create a time
capsule.

&gt;&gt; Stanford athletics supports about 800
scholar athletes in 35 varsity sports.

And it's winner of over 100 NCAA
championships and 18 directors cups.

&gt;&gt; Dedicated in 1941, Hoover Tower is more
than just a nice landmark on campus.

It houses the Hoover Institution on War,
Revolution and Peace.

&gt;&gt; The new Science and Engineering quad at
Stanford is the hub of interdisciplinary

learning and research and home to the
School of Engineering.

&gt;&gt; This is the Graduate School of
Business.

Ranked number one in the country, this is
the newest part of campus.

&gt;&gt; The Yang and Yamazaki Environment and
Energy building is home to Environmental

Science programs in the School of Earth
Sciences.

The Y2E2 building sets a new standard for
sustainable architecture on campus.

&gt;&gt; The Stanford Law School is the oldest
professional school of the university.

Notable alumni include three US Supreme
Court justices.

&gt;&gt; The Stanford School of Medicine is a
world leader in medical training and

research.
The Row offers student housing for Greek

organizations, cultural, and academic
houses.

&gt;&gt; Now we find ourselves in White Plaza,
the center for student life on campus.

At the heart of White Plaza, we have the
Claw Fountain.

Now, one of those traditions that's unique
to Stanford, is fountain hopping.

The Stanford School of Education is the
second oldest school of education in

United States.
It offer its first PhD in 1916.

The Cantor Art Center has a wonderful
collection of works on display.

And one of the largest collections of
Rodin's sculptures outside of Paris.

&gt;&gt; At the end of the day, come finish off
your tour with a hike through the

foothills to the Dish, for some nice
views of campus.

If you are interested in taking a tour
yourself, please come to the Stanford

Visitor Center.
We offer guided tours daily.

For more information, please go to our
website at visit.stanford.edu.

&gt;&gt; Thanks for watching and we hope to see
you here on the farm.

&gt;&gt; For more, please visit us at
stanford.edu.

comments.text:
+DJSerbianSuperman nothing wrong with a regional college. Most private 
schools hhave better faculty student ratios, high quality professors and a 
distinct focus on the undergrad experiance. Even better if you are 
religious affiliated and go to a religious affiliated school. I'd say the 
best regional colleges are comparable to the best liberal arts colleges and 
approach the level of intimacy given at the very best private national 
universities.
comments.author: Robbie Wilson

comments.text:
Lmao, I remember when is as in the 7th grade... I was set on Harvard or 
Stanford, then I fucked up my first two years and that opportunity went 
away. I did so bad my first two years, that my role of president in DECA 
for my school, great GPA for junior & senior year, countless number of 
honors and awards, and AP classes only got me accepted into a regional 
college... Whatever I'll just go to a state school after a year and then 
hopefully get an MBA from an Ivy. Good luck.
comments.author: DJSerbianSuperman

comments.text:
lol you have a long way to go.  Anyway, I'd put Harvard ahead of Stanford 
and Stanford ahead of Brown, it's up to you.  Both Brown and Harvard are 
Ivy's, Stanford isn't, but it has one of the largest endowment funds of the 
non-ivy's.  Frankly, all the above are kick-ass.  Focus on high-school 
first, it's harder than you might think. There is a reason why Stanford has 
The-Lowest-Acceptance-Rates in the country, 5.1% in 2014.  Compare that to 
Harvard at 5.9% and Yale at 6.3%.

comments.text:
+Prince Murukurthy What I'm saying is that while people like to look at the 
Ivy League as something more, all it ACTUALLY is is a football league. 
 Therefore, when you're trying to decide which schools are "best," you 
shouldn't just look at whether they belong to the Ivy League.  Stanford, 
MIT, Duke, and Caltech are all just as fantastic as the top Ivies.  P.S. 
 None of the Ivy League schools (except Princeton) even have ivy on their 
buildings.  Lies, I say!  Go Cardinal!
comments.author: Senor Tree

The ivy league is a group of elite schools centered in the north east 
It is the name of the football league but it is much more than that
comments.author: Prince Murukurthy

comments.text:
You're wrong.  Look it up. Stanford+MIT aren't Ivy League, but they're much 
more prestigious than a majority of the Ivies (UPenn, Cornell, Dartmouth, 
etc.).  The Ivy League, while it has certain connotations, is a football 
league and nothing more.
comments.author: Senor Tree

comments.text:
Actually... Ivy League means that you're one of the Elite schools like Yale 
or Harvard or Princeton...
comments.author: Tilenator

comments.text:
It's not...the Ivy League is actually just a football league that some of 
the older east coast schools formed.  Stanford's football league is the Pac 
12.

comments.author: iOzziKhalya

comments.text:
Sorry, but saying you "can't wait to go to Stanford" is extremely 
quixotic... Getting a 4.0+ GPA, taking the hardest AP classes, getting a 
2000+ SAT score and playing a sport throughout high school will probably 
only get the admissions officers to not throw your application to the side. 
Schools like Stanford want you to apply so they can reject you; having a 
low admissions rate looks good for the school. Plus, living anywhere off of 
campus is unrealistic especially while having to pay off college tuition; 
not trying to put you down, but don't be naive and don't get your hopes up 
- getting accepted to even most UC (university of california) schools is 
notoriously difficult.
comments.author: Marissa Nichols

comments.text:
If you go to their website you can see that they have 4 star housing for 
the undergraduates and for graduates 5 star dorms

comments.text:
+TeeFryingPan
huh? What are you saying. It literally on the Student directory. Can you 
not read it?
no, It's not a Med school Library ..
It's a local Library, and I said I work/Volunteer there, and then, I said I 
am going to a Grad school this year for Medical at New York or Columbia.
What are you saying? There is no Graduate housing, well there is (but not 
called Graduate housing), anyways Its no where near mine. There is "no" 
dorms for each grade, There is only Freshman Dormitory, and after that you 
choose Dorms that is available or you could live outside the Campus.
comments.author: kenny kim

comments.text:
+Cassie Blake hey, we all make mistakes. really, come to my dorm or to the 
Lane Library because I actually volunteer there. If not, I really don't 
care what you say (not to be mean in any way). yes, my GPA was bad but I 
got in and already graduated. Going to either New York University or 
Columbia to get my Med school, because I got rejected by Stanford Med 
Program.
Also if you do plan to visit, make it before 2 weeks because I am leaving 
soon.

comments.author: KazuichiX

comments.text:
All financial aid is need based at Stanford. so if your parents make less 
than 60,000 US dollars a year, your room, board and tuition is covered 
under financial aid. If they make less than 80,0000, your tuition is 
covered. Beyond that, the financial assistance adjusts accordingly. You're 
still able to apply for outside scholarships
comments.author: Vincent Sparacio

comments.text:
